question: 5 (a)
sols_html:
When using Lagrange interpolation, we choose to fit the point with a polynomial of lowest degree that goes through all the points.

We have 100 points, meaning that we need a 99 degree polynomial:

\(p(x)=a_1x^{99}+a_2x^{98}+...+a_{99}x+a_{100}\)
sols_latex:
When using Lagrange interpolation, we choose to fit the point with a
polynomial of lowest degree that goes through all the points.

We have 100 points, meaning that we need a 99 degree polynomial:

$p(x)=a_1x^{99}+a_2x^{98}+...+a_{99}x+a_{100}$
sols_raw:
When using Lagrange interpolation, we choose to fit the point with a polynomial of lowest degree that goes through all the points.

We have 100 points, meaning that we need a 99 degree polynomial:

<math>p(x)=a_1x^{99}+a_2x^{98}+...+a_{99}x+a_{100}</math>
statement_html:
You are given a set of 100 data points (xn, yn) with xn increasing.

(a) Suppose you wish to use Lagrange interpolation to interpolate the data points. What degree of polynomial would you use and why?
statement_latex:
You are given a set of 100 data points \emph{(x\textsubscript{n},
y\textsubscript{n})} with \emph{x\textsubscript{n}} increasing.

\textbf{(a)} Suppose you wish to use Lagrange interpolation to
interpolate the data points. What degree of polynomial would you use and
why?
statement_raw:
You are given a set of 100 data points ''(x<sub>n</sub>, y<sub>n</sub>)'' with ''x<sub>n</sub>'' increasing.

'''(a)''' Suppose you wish to use Lagrange interpolation to interpolate the data points. What degree of polynomial would you use and why?
